author: Felipe Vera" data-date-published="07/03/2024
title: Messi salva a mujer de 90 a√±os de ser secuestrada por el grupo Ham√°s
text:
Un sorprendente testimonio se revel√≥ recientemente con la historia de Ester Cunio , una mujer de 90 a√±os que, en palabras suyas, logr√≥ sobrevivir a un intento de secuestro por el grupo Ham√°s , gracias al futbolista argentino, Lionel Messi , pero ¬øqu√© se sabe sobre este caso?
La mujer de 90 a√±os lo narra a√∫n con sorpresa, con aquella en la que reconoces, influyeron muchos factores m√°s all√° de la suerte, principalmente, por la destreza con la que se conoce act√∫a el grupo Ham√°s .
Mujer de 90 a√±os sobrevive al grupo Ham√°s gracias a Messi En una fragmento compartido por ‚ÄúVoces del 7 de octubre‚Äù, Ester Cunio se sent√≥ frente a las c√°maras y cont√≥ una historia que, si no lo ves, no lo crees, ah√≠ narra c√≥mo el campe√≥n del mundo, Lionel Messi , logr√≥ salvarla, a√∫n sin estar presente.
De acuerdo con su testimonio, la ma√±ana del 7 de octubre se encontraba en su domicilio al sur de Israel cuando personal del grupo Ham√°s toc√≥ su puerta para realizar un secuestro familiar.
La primera reacci√≥n de Cunio fue negar que ten√≠a familia, a pesar de que una noche antes se reuni√≥ con ellos; sin embargo, el grupo puso resistencia y no le crey√≥.
‚ÄúYo no tengo familia. ¬øNo ves? Anda y checa la casa‚Äù, dijo, ‚ÄúT√∫ vienes conmigo, ac√° no va a quedar gente. Todo esto va a ser fuego‚Äù, le respondieron.
Agreg√≥ que una de las principales problem√°ticas que encontr√≥ fue el lenguaje, ya que ella no comprend√≠a lo que dec√≠an estas personas; sin embargo, una palabra el com√∫n los uni√≥, mejor dicho, un apellido: Messi.
‚Äú¬ø¬°Qu√© es Argentina!?‚Äù, le preguntaron, a lo que ella encontr√≥ como punto de referencia el futbol y espec√≠ficamente que de ah√≠ es Messi.
‚ÄúYo soy de donde es Messi‚Äù , dijo la mujer de 90 a√±os. ¬°¬øMessi!? A m√≠ me gusta Messi, respondi√≥ el hombre, quien inmediatamente solt√≥ el arma y la dej√≥ libre.
üí•üá¶üá∑Ester Cunio, 90, was saved on Oct 7 when she told the Hamas terrorist who invaded her Nir Oz home that she came from Lionel Messi country. Eight members of her family were hostages, including grandsons David & Ariel who remain in captivity. #Argentina pic.twitter.com/FXIEFbLFs7
‚Äî Noga Tarnopolsky ◊†◊í◊î ◊ò◊®◊†◊ï◊§◊ï◊ú◊°◊ß◊ô ŸÜŸàÿ∫ÿß ÿ™ÿ±ŸÜŸàÿ®ŸàŸÑÿ≥ŸÉŸäüíô (@NTarnopolsky) March 7, 2024
Mujer de 90 a√±os le pide a Messi que salve a sus nietos Tras contar su historia, Ester Cunio le mand√≥ un mensaje al astro argentino, le pidi√≥ que ruegue porque el grupo Ham√°s no d√© con ellos.
‚ÄúSi √©l sabe que yo lo mencion√© y me salv√©, ahora le pedir√≠a por mis nietos que est√°n ah√≠ encerrados. Le dir√≠a que por favor ruegue a Dios porque son chicos que valen oro‚Äù, culmin√≥.

author: Carla Espinoza Guti√©rrez
title: USDA expedites disaster response following Central Texas flooding
text:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is deploying extensive emergency resources to assist Central Texas communities impacted by recent severe flooding.
‚ÄúAs a native Texan, this disaster is deeply personal, and I want the people of Central Texas to know the USDA will be by their side through the totality of this response and long-term recovery,‚Äù Agriculture Secretary Brooke L. Rollins said.
Multiple disaster assistance programs have been established to support farmers and ranchers. These include crop insurance, livestock indemnity, emergency assistance programs, tree replacement aid, and conservation restoration initiatives. Details and eligibility are available on farmers.gov .
USDA‚Äôs Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) is supporting livestock operations, with guidance available on protecting animals during disasters.
Response efforts involve multiple other federal agencies:
The U.S. Forest Service (USFS) is coordinating with state and local partners to support debris removal, hazard mitigation, and search and rescue operations. Trained crews and incident management teams from Louisiana, Arkansas, and Mississippi have been deployed for debris clearance and hazard reduction, with law enforcement officers assisting in ongoing rescue efforts.
The Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) is monitoring watershed structures, deploying connectivity devices to offices, and coordinating flood control inspections. The agency continues to engage with the Texas Division of Emergency Management and local officials, providing updates on available assistance programs such as the Emergency Watershed Protection Program (EWP).
Nutrition assistance has been expanded to affected households. As of July 8, USDA authorized the use of SNAP benefits for hot food purchases in seven counties through August 7. The agency also waived the 10-day reporting requirement for SNAP households in 21 counties to report food loss, effective through August 4, 2025.
Food safety guidance includes recommendations for residents to reduce foodborne illness risks following flood exposure, such as using only bottled water, discarding flood-exposed foods and porous items, and thoroughly sanitizing utensils and surfaces.
*Featured photo is for reference only.

author: Tribune News Service
title: Buffalo chicken pizza: All the spice with none of the mess
text:
Meredith Deeds | (TNS) Star Tribune
I‚Äôm a big fan of Buffalo chicken wings. The heat and the sourness from the hot sauce, contrasted with the cool, creamy, slightly funky blue cheese dressing, takes chicken to a new level. I love everything about them ‚Äî except the wings.
Eating chicken wings is messy business; I end up with Buffalo sauce up to my elbows. So if I can capture the same elements that make Buffalo chicken wings so good, and use them to top another beloved dish, pizza, that‚Äôs a win-win.
Welcome to this week‚Äôs recipe, Buffalo Chicken Pizza.
OK, I know many of you are thinking ‚Äúif my pizza isn‚Äôt topped with red sauce, mozz and pepperoni, it isn‚Äôt pizza.‚Äù For those of you who feel strongly about what is and isn‚Äôt pizza, you can quietly call this delightful version flatbread.
But no matter what you call it, the flavor combination works well on top of a crisp pizza crust.
Speaking of crust, most people have no idea how quick and easy it is to make your own. You can do it by hand, or in a food processor, which whips up a respectable dough in a flash. It only needs a short time to rise before rolling it out, adding toppings and popping it into the oven.
Yes, if time is of the essence, you can buy pizza crust at the grocery store. If possible, look for the dough that comes in a bag in the deli section. Crust from a tube is less palatable.
When it comes to the toppings, red sauce doesn‚Äôt make an appearance. Instead, cream cheese is mixed with Parmesan cheese and hot sauce (Frank‚Äôs is my choice for anything Buffalo wingish) and slathered over the uncooked crust. Shredded mozzarella is showered over the cream cheese and topped with shredded cooked chicken that‚Äôs been bathed in more hot sauce.
The pizza is baked to bubbly, browned perfection and drizzled with blue cheese dressing. Either thinly sliced celery or green onions can be used as a garnish.
You may still need a napkin after eating this pizza, but you won‚Äôt need a shower.
Buffalo Chicken Pizza Makes 2 (12-inch) pizzas.
Although making your own pizza crust is ultra-easy, if preferred, you can substitute with 2 (12-ounce) packages of store-bought pizza dough. From Meredith Deeds.
For the crust:
3 1/2 c. (420 g) unbleached flour 1 (2 1/4 tsp.) pkg. dry yeast 2 tsp. salt 1 tsp. sugar 1 1/4 c. (283 g) lukewarm water 1 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil Cornmeal for dusting For the topping:
8 oz. cream cheese, room temperature 3/4 c. grated Parmesan cheese 1/4 c. plus 2 tbsp. Frank‚Äôs Red Hot Original Sauce 1/2 tsp. garlic powder 2 c. shredded mozzarella 2 c. shredded cooked chicken 1/3 c. blue cheese dressing Sliced green onions or celery, for garnish Directions
To make the crust: In a large bowl, combine the flour, yeast, salt and sugar. Create a well in the center of the dry mixture.
Pour the water and olive oil into the well. Stir the mixture together until the dough comes together. Knead the dough with your hands until mixed and smooth. Dough may be sticky and you may need to sprinkle a little more flour on it, but don‚Äôt add too much. The dough should be very soft.
Form dough into a ball, place in an oiled bowl and cover with a clean towel or plastic wrap. Let rise for an hour at room temperature or refrigerate overnight, and let stand at room temperature for 1 hour before shaping. (Alternately, combine all the crust ingredients in the bowl of a food processor and pulse several times until the dough comes together in a ball. No need to knead with your hands. Let rise in the closed food processor bowl for 1 hour.)
Thirty minutes before making the pizza, preheat the oven to 450 degrees and place a pizza stone, tiles or a large baking sheet turned upside down on the lowest rack.
To make the topping: In a medium bowl, combine the cream cheese, Parmesan cheese, 2 tablespoons hot sauce and garlic powder.
In another bowl, combine the chicken with the remaining 1/4 cup hot sauce.
To make the pizza: Divide the dough into 2 pieces. Working with 1 piece at a time, on a floured work surface, roll out to a 10- by 14-inch oblong or, if preferred, a 12-inch circle. Place on a pizza peel or a large rimless baking sheet.
Top with half of the cream cheese mixture, half of the mozzarella and half of the chicken mixture. Carefully slide the pizza off the peel or baking sheet onto the hot pizza stone, tiles or baking sheet. Bake for 12 to 15 minutes or until the crust is browned and cheese is melted. Remove from the oven and cut into 8 pieces. Repeat with remaining dough and toppings.
Drizzle the top of each pizza with half of the blue cheese dressing and garnish with sliced green onions or celery.
____
Meredith Deeds is a cookbook author and food writer from Edina. Reach her at meredithdeeds@gmail.com . Follow her on Instagram ¬≠at @meredithdeeds.
¬©2024 StarTribune. Visit at startribune.com . Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

author: pcAdminPNG
title: National Fisheris Impact Projects
text:
The National Fisheries Authority on Thursday commissioned various community-impact projects in Gotomi in Yelia local level government area in Lufa district, Eastern Highlands Province.
These are one staff house for Gotomi Technical Vocational Training and its parametre fencing that is already in place, two 4-in-1 classrooms and a basket court for Gotomi Primary School in ward six and Lagaiyu Integrated Fish Farm in ward three, all within the Gotomi community.
The staff house that is being commissioned at Gotomi Technical Vocational Education Training centre. Lufa District Development Authority chief executive officer Demo Imara leading the National Fisheries Authority managing director Justin Ilakini and his team for the opening of two 4-in-one classrooms and a basketball court at Gotomi Primary School. Locals joining the Gotomi Primary School community to welcome the National Fisheries Authority managing director Justin Ilakini and his team. Locals turn up in numbers to witness the commissioning of two 4-in-1 classrooms at Gotomi Primary School. The two classrooms that are being commissioned at Gotomi Primary School. The Eastern Highlands provincial education director Wesley Albert giving a speech before the cutting of ribbon to mark the official opening of the classrooms and basketball at Gotomi Primary School. Locals turned up in numbers to witness the launching of Lagaiyu Integrated Fish Farm in ward three of Yelia LLG in Lufa district, Eastern Highlands Province National Fisheries Authority managing director Justin Ilakini (third from right) landed at Gotomi Technical Vocational Education Training centre to commission various community-impact projects in Yelia local level government area in Lufa district, Eastern Highlands Province. The Eastern Highlands provincial director for agriculture, fisheries and Livestock, Awesa Webster, cutting the ribbon to mark the launching of Lagaiyu Integrated Fish Farm while the National Fisheries Authority managing director Justin Ilakini and others look on. The ponds of the Lagaiyu Integrated Fish Farm in ward three of the Yelia local level government area of Lufa district, Eastern Highlands Province. The NFA managing director, Justin Ilakini, along with the senior staff and technical officers, flew in to commission these projects.
Led by the provincial corporate service director, Peter Gare, the provincial administration team comprising the senior officers from the divisions of education and natural resources, along with the Lufa District Development Authority chief executive officer, Demo Imara, joined the NFA delegation for the occasion.
The people of Lufa turned up in numbers to warmly welcome them.
Impressed with the positive impacts these projects are having on this geographically disadvantaged communities, especially during dry seasons, and convinced of the need areas to improve further, Mr Ilakini assured the people of more assistant to improve further.
Read more on Post Courier next week.

author: FIRST ALERT WEATHER
title: chevron-right
text: Two men are facing charges in connection with a 2023 fatal shooting in Southeast D.C., according to Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) officials. On December 16, 2023, officers responded to the report of gunshots in the 1200 block of 44th Place, Southeast around 8:07 p.m. When they arrived on the scene, officers found a man suffering from gunshot wounds. The man was taken to a hospital where he died from his injuries, according to officials. READ MORE | Groups of teens in DC commit 2 separate crime sprees in 2 weeks The man was later identified as Kenneth Barksdale, Jr., 28, of Southeast, officials said. On Wednesday, July 31, officers arrested an 18-year-old from Southeast. He was charged with first-degree murder, according to officials On Thursday, August 1, officers arrested Eric Sheffield, 19, of Northeast and charged him with first-degree murder. The case remains under investigation, and anyone with information is asked to call 202-727-9099 or text a tip to 50411.

author: CBS Minnesota
title: Snowy, wet weather changes Halloween plans in Minnesota
text: For some it's a trick, for others, it's a treat. The snow is changing how we celebrate Halloween. Adam Duxter shares how the celebration is weathering the storm.
